titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Norman D. Rabinovitz Photograph Collection, 1965-1999 AIS.2010.16
titlestmt.author: Karen Dettloff.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:53:06 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Norman D. Rabinovitz Photograph Collection largely comprises the images he took as a medical photographer at Allegheny General Hospital and Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, now UPMC Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. His medical photography covers broad topics ranging from physicians to surgical procedures, hospitalized children, and medical equipment. The collection also documents his work as a photographer for University of Pittsburgh archaeological digs, his travels, photo experimentation, and Pittsburgh among other topics.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: In 2011 Mr. Rabinovitz donated photographs specifically relating to the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh to the hospital.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Norman D. Rabinovitz was born in 1935 in the Hill District neighborhood of Pittsburgh and grew up on Bryn Mawr Road.

After high school, Rabinovitz entered the University of Pittsburgh to study philosophy. He was drafted into the Air Force where he served for four years, teaching photography at the Air Force Service Club. Upon his return to Pitt, he changed his study to communications. Teaching and sharing his knowledge of photography was important to Rabinovitz even after his work with the Air Force. Once back in Pittsburgh he taught courses at the Brashear Association, the Kingsley Association, and the Art Institute of Pittsburgh as well as in the Free University program sponsored by the University of Pittsburgh.

Rabinovitz was hired as a medical photographer at Allegheny General Hospital in 1962. After one year there, he moved to the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh in 1963. He remained at Children's for 38 years where he retired as director of medical photography. His medical photography covered broad topics ranging from physicians to surgical procedures, hospitalized children, and medical equipment. He was also an occasional photographer for the local newspaper, Oakland. Additionally, Rabinovitz participated as a photographer for University of Pittsburgh archaelogical digs excavating Neolithic pits at Öcsöd-Kovashalom, which took place in 1971. He was an avid experimenter in photographic techniques, becoming called upon to test new products such as Kodak's infrared film and Polaroid's Polachrome.

While Rabinovitz has contributed much to photography on a world-wide scale, one of his significant accomplishments was in saving the work of noted photographer Esther Bubley from the dumpster. His rescue of her Children's Hospital photographs, taken in 1951 when Bubley was part of the Pittsburgh Photographic Library project, helped preserve them. By bringing Bubley's photographs to the attention of local documentary filmmaker Ken Love and his wife, pediatrician Barbara McNulty, MD, the award winning documentary, That's Pediatrics, was able to be made. Rabinovitz's association with Ken Love led to collaborations on a film on the life and work of Samuel Rosenberg and photographer, Charles "Teenie" Harris. Rabinovitz also collaborated with friends and fellow photographers Herb Ferguson, Stephan Lorant, Eugene Smith, and Roy Stryker. He also collaborated with Dr. Sylvan Stool on films relating to otoscopy.
Rabinovitz has been a member of the Royal Photographic Society, and a Photomicroscopist. His photography has appeared in several books and journals including:
Rubin, Judith Aron. Art therapy: an introduction. Philadelphia, PA: Brunner/Mazel, 1999.
Rubin, Judith Aron, and Judith Aron Rubin. Introduction to art therapy: sources & resources .New York: Routledge, 2010.
Bernardo, Lisa Marie, Marianne Bove, and Raymond B. Karasic. Pediatric emergency nursing procedures. Boston: Jones and Bartlett, 1993.
Rabinovits lives in Pittsburgh with his wife Nancy.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Norman D. Rabinovitz Photograph Collection contains photos and other items dating from 1965 to 1999. The collection contains approximately 13,940 items found in a variety of formats including photographic prints, color and black and white negatives, 35mm slides, and manuscript materials. Because of overlapping subjects contained within some groups of photographs, it was not possible to separate them according to topic. They remain as organized by the photographer.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Karen Dettloff in 2012-2013.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Norman D. Rabinovitz Photograph Collection, 1965-1999, AIS.2010.16, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series V. University of Pittsburgh Archaelogical Dig

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Norman D. Rabinovitz in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series document his interest in the work of noted photographer, Roy Stryker. Items include photographs taken of Roy Stryker, articles written about Stryker, and materials relating to photographic projects on which Stryker worked.

did.unittitle: Pittsburgh Rivers- Roy Stryker in Pittsburgh- Pittsburgh Skyline
News Articles Related to Roy Stryker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The images in this series document medical procedures and medical life as well as surgeries, x-rays, testing, cells, and physicians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The images in this series document Pittsburgh. Views include Three Rivers Stadium, the University of Pittsburgh, various Pittsburgh neighborhoods such as Downtown, Oakland, and the South Side, Nine Mile Run development, the Pittsburgh Folk Festival, Stouffer's Restaurant, railroads, sporting events, and other topics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Includes Paul Simon, Ike and Tina Turner, Nancy Reagan, Debbie Reynolds, and Gloria Steinem among others.

did.unittitle: Pittsburgh Symphony- Andre Previn and Itzhak Perlman
Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railway Yard
Cathedral of Learning and Oakland Views
University of Pittsburgh Law School Construction
Pitt Stadium, Three Rivers Stadium, Forbes Field
Pitt Stadium, Three Rivers Stadium, and Forbes Field
University of Pittsburgh Swimming and Diving

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Portraits of Dr. Mark Ravich, Albert Ferguson, Phil Fireman, and Dr, Henry T. Bahnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The images in this series contain travel photographs of monuments, people, various locations in the United States as well as the Cayman Islands, Spain, Yugoslavia, Greece, Turkey, England, and Switzerland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains images documenting a University of Pittsburgh archeological dig excavating Neolithic pits at Öcsöd-Kovashalom, which took place in 1971. Included are views of artifacts, the dig, and those who participated in the project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The images in this series document Rabinovitz's work with photographic experimentation in a variety of settings and using various techniques to achieve the desired effects.

did.unittitle: Early American Room (Cathedral of Learning, University of Pittsburgh)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes images of plants and animal life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The images in this series cover many subjects including animals, inanimate objects, plant life, city shots, advertisements and people. Several are copy photographs taken for projects. These items bear no description or collection origination information.

did.unittitle: Bird Banding and Old Time Cooking

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This group contains contact sheets and accompanying 35mm black and white negatives. Subjects covered include nature, archaeology, Pittsburgh, and photographic experimentation. Because many subjects appear together on the same contact sheets and sleeves, they remain as orginzed by the photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This group contains contact sheets and accompanying negatives. Subjects covered include photo experimentation, Pittsburgh images. An original note indicated that these may have been items Rabinovitz wished to print. Because many subjects appear together on the same contact sheets and sleeves, they remain as orginzed by the photographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This group contains 35mm slides covering a variety of subjects and photographic experimentation Because many subjects appear together on the same contact sheets and sleeves, they remain as orginzed by the photographer.

scopecontent.p: Unidentified copy photographs taken for projects. No specific collection or original owner is identified.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains manuscript materials that includes documentation surrounding the University of Pittsburgh archeological dig on which he particapted as photographer, journal articles for which Norman Rabinowitz provided photographs, journal articles and papers he wrote, research materials, and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains oversized versions of images that can be found throughout the collection. These include an autographed picture of Roy Stryker addressed to Norman Rabinowitz and views of renovations to "The Bank" which is now the Point Park University Library.
